intro: Peucedanum serotinum, commonly known as late hogweed, is a biennial or perennial herbaceous plant native to Central and Eastern Europe. It features a tall, hollow stem that can reach up to 2 meters in height, often with purple spots and longitudinal veins. The plant produces large, umbrella-like compound leaves that are deeply lobed and covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are small and white, arranged in dense, clustered inflorescences, and it is part of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley. The plant is known for its toxic sap, which can cause severe skin irritation and photosensitivity.
